timeline.bodyText:
I'm not sure about this change because it replaces something that was clear (enabled) with something less clear - ie. defaultEnabled is not the same as defaultEnabled() and is not actually the "default" , but a combination of the default with a configuration override.
AFAICT this change is just so the scala instrumentations can see if the instrumentation is enabled from the POV of the base class - is there a reason they can't use super.enabled() to do that?
timeline.author: mcculls

replies.bodyText: Sure, I can change it back to enabled. I can see how confusing defaultEnabled is, even though enabled is a bit misleading as well.
replies.author: bantonsson

timeline.bodyText: this change is fine, but I think the other changes in this file are unnecessary given subclasses can call super.isEnabled() to get the enabled state of the base class which they can then override in their isEnabled method
